comment: It was a good explanation of the calculations although I wish he would have explained WHY you would want to find the root mean square of a group of values. Root Mean Square (RMS) is a statistical measure used to quantify the average magnitude of a set of values. It involves taking the square root of the arithmetic mean of the squared values, providing a more accurate representation of the overall magnitude while accounting for variations and fluctuations within the dataset. The Root Mean Square (RMS) formula is a mathematical expression used to calculate the square root of the average of the squares of a set of values. It is particularly useful for finding a representative value that reflects the magnitude of a set of data points, while also taking into account both positive and negative values.
Why do we take square of the velocities and not modulus?
Good way to present the concept.... very helpful
Sir you are calculating rms of velocity, but you are pronounciating speed. Why??
Are you going to follow up with when and why you’d use each one?
@nickbutler7390  so is it actually speed or velocity? and what would happen if i considered average velocity instead of avg speed? would the result be zero?
@shafaatjamil7765  depends on what you have been asked

We use RMS to calculate average values that are negative and positive. We look at it as a total magnitude of each value. For example is you're measuring vibrations, your data could be be negative and positive(vibrating up and down) but say we care about the average vibration distance(regardless of direction), we use RMS  in this case.
@foxmccloud9548  truee cause it if you added positive and negative values it would be the true speed of each particle more of an average which would approach zero?
